author: Eliot Shorr-Parks | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: With Odell Beckham Jr. expected to play, how can Eagles stop Giants' top playmaker?
text:
It looks like luck is not on the Eagles ' side.
According to a report by NJ Advance Media , Giants wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. is expected to play against the Eagles on Monday night, despite suffering from a hamstring injury he suffered last week.
Although you never want a player to be injured, there is no denying that the Eagles wouldn't have minded Beckham taking an extra week to rest his injured hamstring, especially given the importance of Monday night's game.
MORE : Giants' Odell Beckham Jr. expected to play Monday night vs. Eagles, per sources
Obviously, with any hamstring injury, Beckham's status will be worth monitoring throughout the game. Especially with a player like Beckham, who is one of the fastest receivers in the NFL, a hamstring injury could seriously impact his ability on Monday night.
Now that he is expected to be out on the field, however, the question is -- how will the Eagles stop him?
The Eagles didn't have much luck last season containing Beckham. The last time the two teams met, Beckham caught 12 passes for 185 yards and a touchdown, but that was against an Eagles' secondary that has since been torn apart and rebuilt.
Head coach Chip Kelly spent big money on cornerback Byron Maxwell , and also brought in cornerback Walter Thurmond, who has since turned into a stellar safety. The team also promoted Nolan Carroll to starting cornerback.
WHO WILL WIN: Eagles or Giants? Against the Giants on Monday night, it will be interesting to see how defensive coordinator Billy Davis deploys his new secondary against Beckham.
Speaking earlier in the week, Maxwell revealed that the team doesn't plan on having how shadow Beckham. While there could be some gamesmanship at work, with Maxwell unlikely to reveal the team's plan, that isn't surprising. Davis and secondary coach Cory Undlin have yet to have a cornerback shadow a receiver throughout the game so far this season, and Davis didn't do it last year either.
Part of the problem with having a player shadow Beckham is how much the Giants move him around. Beckham lines up both on the outside and in the slot, and sometimes even lines up in the back field. Although Maxwell does have some experience in slot coverage, asking him to chase Beckham around all night might be too much to ask of any cornerback.
Assuming the Eagles don't shadow Beckham, Davis' decision will be whether or not to give his cornerbacks help over the top.
Last year, Davis left his cornerbacks in man coverage against Beckham, and the results were ugly. Davis has shown this season he isn't afraid to leave his cornerbacks out on an island, as he did it time-and-time against the Atlanta Falcons in Week 1, a game where wide receiver Julio Jones torched the Eagles' secondary.
More than likely, Davis is going to trust whatever cornerback lines up across from Beckham to cover him.
If Davis learned a lesson from last year, and from earlier this season, he will give that cornerback safety help over the top, not asking one player to stop Beckham on his own.
A task no cornerback has shown he is able to do -- even if Beckham might not be 100%.
